reviewText: The only thing I knew about Rosa Parks was the bus incident and that's all the movie seemed to show.  There were some memorable moments like when she was a child some of her friends switched the signs on the drinking fountains so the whites were now using the coloured one.  A white man used the fountain and let his dog use the coloured one.  Then there was the time when Rosa was in school and she saw a girl tracing her shoe outline onto a piece of paper because coloured people couldn't try things on at stores.  When I watched this movie, I got a sense that the NAACP used Rosa Parks to further their cause.  No one there seemed to have an guts so they used Rosa.  This isn't a movie I'd recommend, there's just nothing to it.

summary: Good concept of self discipline and power of choice

reviewText: This wasn't just about what Rosa Parks did, it was about Rosa Parks the person.  Angela Bassett, I'm a fan!  She does a good job with the feature role making this version a more biopic event and not a hollywood made for the screen event.  A lot is revealed here and I encourage those of you who only know about what she did on that bus to get this DVD and see more about the woman then that event.

reviewText: We loved this movie!  We are in our late 60's  and remembered her ordeal on the bus ride.  I am STILL embarrassed that some white passenger did not stand up for her!  Anyway, the movie is wonderful and gives a lot of history about her that we did not know.  It should be seen by everyone...especially the younger generations!  They need to know about this awful history!  Angela did a great job too!

reviewText: a pinfully good movie, bitter sweet..,good 'cause it was the start of the civil right movement, a story that need to be told,her brave act and sacrifice was not in vain,she tore down barriers,she sat in the back so you could sit in the front,and when enough was enough she took a stand and refused to be a victim of the racist south,,,,the God ugly truth of how white people treated people of color is exposed, but not in the severity that it realy was, guess white people cant stomach the whole truth and hold back so the world of today don't see them for who they realy are and shame runs cold in their blood,, Rosa Parks is an American hero who changed the face of America,,todays youth would do good to watch this movie and see the truth of how grand'ma and grampa' called themselves Christians yet treated their neighbors like animals

reviewText: I was fascinated by this movie and learned a lot about Rosa Parks and the uphill battle that she faught for what most people take for granted. Initially, even her husband did not support what she was trying to do. Angela Bassett was outstanding in her performance of the story of a true civil rights pioneer. I would definitely recommend this film especially for young people.

reviewText: Whatever you are about to pay for this movie is well worth it!  A beautiful story about a somewhat shy but determined lady who changed history.  I never knew her full story which is full of sorrow and needless pain because of ignorance.The acting is outstanding as well, with a superb cast and story that will truly tear at your heart.  It did mine.

reviewText: Besides the history of the bus incident, I didn't know much about Rosa Parks. This story delves into how the conflict between Rosa fighting with the NAACP affected her family. Although some may find it to be a borderline story about relationships, I liked the story for that exact reason. It gave me a different view of how to look at a political situation that can hinder the people around you (for example, job loss, physical danger, voting rights). The focus of the story was on how Rosa Parks grew up not being able to understand the tactics of Jim Crow laws. Because her mother was just as strong as she, and her husband was initially a fighter as well, even someone who was unfamiliar with her would understand how she became so politically active.Instead of creating the book in a documentary, it was entertaining, sometimes romantic, political, controversial, and informative all wrapped into one movie. Angela Bassett was a great choice to play Rosa Parks and I loved Peter Francis James as her husband, Raymond Parks. This was the first time I'd seen this actor in anything and it made me want to become more familiar with his projects.Overall, great job. A friend of mine said that too many parts were left out about how Rosa Parks dealt with poverty later on, and I would surely like to see another movie go into the next segment of her life. Had it been in this one, it might've dragged on, but I would've enjoyed seeing that in the extras. The extras were rather disappointing--things like timelines are something I can find in an African American dominated textbook (they tend to be more accurate than the biased books that the Board of Education enforces). I would've liked to have seen actual interviews with Rosa Parks or how the actors were affected by doing a movie on this icon.From the segments I got, it does make me want to move on and read more about her though.

reviewText: The story of the civil rights heroine whose refusal to obey racial bus segregation was just one of her acts in her fight for justice. The performance of Angela Bassett in this movie is great.  Rosa Parks serves as a shining inspiration to many Americans, and she has instilled in them, the indispensable spirituality, to covet the privilege of freedom, and to cherish the right of equality.
